description:
Agrococcus citreus is a species of bacteria that belongs to the Actinobacteria class. It is a Gram-positive, coccoid-shaped bacterium that typically appears in pairs or clusters. Agrococcus citreus is known for its ability to produce a characteristic lemon-yellow pigment, which is attributed to the presence of carotenoid compounds.

This bacterium is commonly found in soil and has been isolated from various environmental samples, including agricultural and forest soils. Agrococcus citreus is considered a non-pathogenic bacterium and is not known to cause any known human or animal diseases.

Physiologically, Agrococcus citreus is aerobic, meaning it requires oxygen for growth and metabolism. It is also mesophilic, thriving at moderate temperatures typically found in the natural environment. The bacterium is capable of utilizing a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, contributing to its adaptability in diverse soil ecosystems.

Agrococcus citreus has been the subject of scientific interest due to its potential applications in biotechnology, such as the production of industrially relevant enzymes or the remediation of environmental contaminants. Its distinctive pigmentation and metabolic capabilities make it a unique member of the Actinobacteria family.
